text: [Music]
Uh it was a wonderful experience uh for
a lot of reasons partly because of the
other kids who were involved but
actually one thing that's important is
that I wasn't so much a debate champ as
a guy who did it and made a lot of
friends but I think that actually the
more formative experience was losing and
losing frequently. Uh, and I remember
that I felt at the time as though I had
an agenda and whenever I would go in to
give some sort of extemporaneous speech
or something like that, I remember I
kind of had certain thoughts and I was
like, I want to convey these um I want
to proitize. I want to like challenge
people and provoke people and winning is
secondary and you know mainly it was
just this thought I have this
opportunity to have a captive audience
and these people have to listen to me
for seven minutes and uh I think that I
didn't necessarily take away entirely
good lessons from that experience but it
was magical. It was just a group of
really idiosyncratic kids and
particularly the ones who didn't go to
my high school. I went to a public
magnet high school, but there were these
other kids from Catholic high schools
who had these really different
backgrounds. And I was struck by I was
someone who had never met someone who
was a Republican, a conservative,
someone who was uh pro-life. And through
debate, I met all of these people and
was just kind of dazzled by the range of
opinions that really exist in the world.
Uh and it had a huge huge effect on me
and just having respect for people who
have different ways of engaging. Um and
just yeah being around people for whom
you know being quick and verbal that was
uh you know the way that you were
veilorized you know what I mean it was
quite neat and more important to me than
I I don't reflect on it as much as
perhaps I should.
That's a really good question. I lately
I've been really drawn to thinkers like
um I've been around to thinkers like
Casey Mulligan. He's a good example.
He's an economist at the University of
Chicago who in some ways is accused of
really radically oversimplifying things.
Uh you know he uh likes single good
models of the world. Um he really likes
um also he uses very arresting language.
Um you know he has talked a lot in the
context of the recent recession about um
about work disincentives and what a
powerful role they play. And people are
oftenimes offended by this. Like are you
saying that people have decided to go on
a vacation and that's why they're
unemployed? And the beauty of him is
that he's so not embedded in a kind of
social cultural context of the kind of
nicities and the kind of obligatory
things that one says that it's just
really arresting to read this kind of
200p proof version of uh you know kind
of his particular style of argument. I
love it. Um, I also think that Paul
Krugman is a tremendously um, impressive
voice, you know, coming from a kind of
diametrically opposed worldview. Um, and
Krugman is someone that I find sometimes
pretty tendentious. Uh, but that's part
of what's so impressive about him. he's
able to kind of construct this kind of
coherent argument that again you could
think wait a second wait I I don't buy
that or I I don't buy this but he it's
like a freight train and you know kind
of once he leaves the station you know
it's suddenly as though well if you
disagree with me you're clearly an
unreasonable and perhaps even dangerous
person uh and you know that's admirable
in a sense that's certainly not my my
own style
